2.12.1.title: Overview
2.12.1.content:
Well intervention operations include wireline, coiled tubing, and snubbing operations performed on producing or completed wells.

**Key Differences from Drilling:**
- Well may be live (under pressure)
- Completion equipment in place
- Different barrier systems
- Specialized intervention equipment

**Well Control Principles:**
- Two barriers required at all times
- SSSV (Subsurface Safety Valve) often provides one barrier
- Intervention BOP provides second barrier
- Well should be in known, stable condition before entry

2.12.2.title: Wireline Well Control
2.12.2.content:
**Barrier System:**
- Primary: Well fluid + Wireline BOP + Lubricator + Grease seals
- Secondary: SSSV or equivalent downhole barrier

**Equipment:**
- Wireline BOP (rams to cut wire, blind rams)
- Lubricator for tool deployment
- Grease injection system
- Stuffing box

**Kick Indicators:**
- Unexpected cable weight changes
- Fluid at stuffing box
- Pressure changes
- Flow from vent lines

**Response:**
1. Stop cable movement
2. Close wireline BOP
3. Cut cable if necessary to secure well
4. Investigate cause before resuming

**Prevention:**
- Verify well conditions before entry
- Test SSSV function
- Use proper lubricator pressure rating
- Have kill fluid available

2.12.3.title: Coiled Tubing Well Control
2.12.3.content:
**Barrier System:**
- Primary: Well fluid + CT BOP + Check valves in CT
- Secondary: SSSV or tubing plug + Production casing/cement

**Equipment:**
- CT BOP (shear rams, slip rams, blind rams)
- Stripper/injector head
- Check valves in CT string
- Circulating system

**Kick Indicators:**
- Weight indicator anomalies
- Returns composition change
- Pressure changes
- Flow from annulus

**Response:**
1. Stop CT movement
2. Close appropriate BOP element
3. Assess situation
4. May need to circulate out through CT
5. Pull CT if safe to do so

**Special Considerations:**
- CT has limited weight capacity
- May be snubbing (pipe light)
- Check valves may fail
- Smaller ID limits circulation rate

2.12.4.title: Snubbing Well Control
2.12.4.content:
**When Used:**
- Need to run tubing/drillpipe into live well
- Pipe is light relative to wellhead pressure
- Cannot strip conventionally

**Barrier System:**
- Primary: Snubbing BOP + IBOP/check valves
- Secondary: Production BOP + casing/cement

**Procedure:**
1. Install snubbing unit on wellhead
2. Test all barriers
3. Run pipe in using hydraulic force
4. Manage pressure as pipe enters/exits
5. Volumetric considerations apply

**Well Control:**
- Multiple BOPs available
- Can close and strip through various elements
- Constant pressure management required
- Specialized crew and equipment

2.12.5.title: General Intervention Well Control
2.12.5.content:
**Before Entry:**
1. Confirm well is in safe condition
2. Test SSSV (or install tubing plug)
3. Install and test intervention BOP
4. Have kill fluid available
5. Brief crew on barriers and response

**During Operations:**
- Maintain awareness of barrier status
- Monitor for any unusual indications
- Stop work if barriers compromised
- Clear communication on well status

**Response to Well Control Event:**
1. Stop operations immediately
2. Close intervention BOP
3. Verify SSSV/downhole barrier status
4. Assess situation
5. Implement kill procedure if needed
6. Do not resume until barriers restored

**Kill Methods:**
- Bullhead through tubing or annulus
- Circulate if path available
- Dynamic kill with pumping
- May need to close SSSV and kill above it

2.12.6.title: SSSV Considerations
2.12.6.content:
**Role in Intervention:**
- Provides downhole barrier
- Typically set 100-500 ft below surface
- Normally held open by hydraulic pressure
- Fails closed when pressure removed

**Before Intervention:**
- Test SSSV closure and opening
- Verify seal integrity
- Know depth and specifications

**During Intervention:**
- Maintain hydraulic control
- Be prepared to close if needed
- Tools passing through SSSV must fit

**If SSSV Not Functional:**
- Must install alternative barrier
- Wireline set plug, or
- Tubing plug, or
- Other mechanical barrier
- Two barriers required at all times

**Emergency Closure:**
- If well control event occurs, SSSV can be closed
- Traps tools below it
- Secures well, tools retrieved later
